entry.title: What is HANA Calculation View Modeling and is it for me?
entry.content:
SAP HANA Calculation View modeling was introduced with the launch of SAP HANA back in 2010 and has become one of the most popular and sought-after skills in SAP Analytics. If you are wondering if this topic is for you, and you would like a brief description of what is it and what can be achieved, then read on.

SAP HANA Calculation View modeling is your tool of choice for modeling analytic scenarios with SAP HANA Cloud. It allows preprocessing and preparation of your data to harvest them in analytic clients. With calculation views you implement your business logic using an intuitive graphical interface.

Graphical Calculation View Editor

 

By the close integration of calculation views into SAP HANA you leverage the full potential of the performance of SAP HANA using several pruning and many more techniques.

Some Performance Optimization Options

 

Being fully integrated into SAP HANA development tooling you benefit from enterprise ready lifecycle management.

Integrated Version Control

Similarly, you can count on enterprise ready features such as multi-language support.

Support of Multiple Languages

 

SAP is working on deepening the bidirectional integration with SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) so that calculation views seamlessly integrate into BDC modeling while at the same time opening the venue to integrate BDC data products into HANA Cloud via calculation views.

 

Reporting on calculation views is pretty flexible. You can use SQL statements, SQL based tools, or you can build on the SAP ecosystem around SAP Cloud Analytics. This gives you the free choice around analytic clients. Calculation views automatically generate metadata during their deployment so that analytic clients know how to best access, display, and analyze the data. For example, information about expected prompts or type of data and their meaning are available as metadata.

 

Documentation about Meta Data

The graphical building blocks of calculation views make it easy to extend your logic and to visualize the implemented logic to your stakeholders.

 

Imagine you are asked to provide up to date sales data every morning. Instead of handcrafting a SQL statement you create a calculation view that combines the relevant technical tables in joins. This way you neither have to hand over a SQL statement nor do you need to assume that the stakeholder understands your SQL statement. Instead you point your stakeholder to the created calculation view. By enriching the calculation view with semantically meaningful data, e.g., business partner data you ensure that the report is grounded in a meaningful context.

Calculation view modeling has developed from the on-premise SAP HANA Studio tooling via the on premise browser based SAP Web IDE for HANA to the cloud tooling SAP Business Application Studio. It is embedded into the SAP Build Code environment to make sure that you can integrate it with all the other BTP development options.

Target User

HANA calculation views are the first stop if you want to encode your technical knowledge about data and tables into an easy to consume model. You can integrate data from different sources either directly with calculation views using the remote capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud or you integrate your calculation views into SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to leverage the ecosystem of BDC with its enhanced capabilities to enrich calculation views with additional business semantics. If you are a data expert with a familiarity to databases, calculation views are your tool of choice to leverage database performance techniques while creating semantically meaningful units of reporting. Whether your purpose is to analyse large data sets or your purpose is to provide meaningful analytic reports - calculation views are your choice: Calculation views provide an easy and flexible way to build up complex scenarios in a structured manner and keep the scenarios easily adaptable and maintainable to bring the required agility into your development process.

Got interested? Read about new innovations around calculation views by visiting the blog on new calculation view features

Visit the FAQ blog for frequently asked questions

entry.title: Explore SAP Business AI Innovations on SAP Roadmap Explorer Today
entry.content:
At SAP, we are committed to embedding AI capabilities directly into our core applications and processes with SAP Business AI, designed to deliver tangible, real-world business outcomes across the enterprise.  

Navigating this dynamic landscape is key: understanding what’s coming next, when features or agents are available, and how they could improve end-to-end business processes. 

That’s why we are thrilled to announce a new and dedicated roadmap experience for SAP Business AI on the SAP Roadmap Explorer website available today. 

This new experience encompasses: 

  • A new banner on the SAP Roadmap Explorer home page 
  • A new ‘Strategic Topics’ menu where SAP Business AI is featured 
  • A new business view page for SAP Business AI that offers the transparency you need into SAP’s AI product strategy, development priorities, and upcoming innovations.  

Let's focus on the new business view page, which is a perfect asset to move from high-level announcements to access granular details about specific AI features and agents and their anticipated release timelines. 

This allows you to deep dive into the different road map priorities per Line of Business (LoB), such as Spend Management or Human Capital Management, giving you deeper insights to make informed, timely decisions that drive tangible business outcomes.  
You can rapidly evaluate SAP’s AI offerings against your unique business requirements, thereby accelerating your innovation cycles.  

The roadmap acts as a living document, reducing the risk of making uninformed decisions based on outdated or incomplete information.  

You can also leverage the latest ‘notification’ feature available on SAP Roadmap Explorer by clicking on the ‘subscribe’ button on the right-hand side of the page to get notified as soon as it’s updated by SAP. 

By providing transparency and ability to deep dive into LoB-specific innovations across time, it empowers everyone to confidently embark on their AI journey, maximize investments, and harness the transformative power of SAP Business AI.  

We encourage all SAP Community members, customers, and partners to regularly visit roadmap.sap.com and explore the future of SAP Business AI.

entry.title: Re: Introducing Application Vulnerability Report for Cloudfoundry Applications – Try It Now!
entry.content:
Hi @Harjyot, 

thanks for your questions! To answer them:

Does the service (or its API) cover scanning of HTML5/custom UI5 applications deployed in SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry) and also in on‑premise landscapes, or is it limited to CF runtime apps?

Our service scans applications deployed on the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtime and does not cover on-premise landscapes.

Regarding HTML5/UI5 applications, they are covered under the following conditions:

  • The application must be deployed on the Cloud Foundry runtime.
  • The scan focuses on identifying vulnerabilities within the application's open-source components and dependencies.

 

Can we retrieve a list of direct and transitive npm/pip packages (from package-lock.json and similar), plus severity findings per component via the API? What output formats are supported?

Yes, the API provides the necessary information to address those needs.

  • List of Packages: The API response includes a packageNames field, which is an array containing the names of the components where vulnerabilities were found. Our underlying scan identifies vulnerabilities across the entire dependency tree.
  • Severity Findings: The API gives detailed severity information for each finding through:
    • maxCvss: highest CVSS score, providing a standard numerical severity rating.
    • priority: simplified priority level.
    • activeCves: list of specific CVEs associated with the component.
    • description and recommendation: textual details about the vulnerability and how to remediate it.
  • Output Format: The API supports the JSON format for its output, as seen by the data model.

Frequency: the blog mentions weekly scans. Are there options to configure a different cadence, or trigger on-demand scans?

Right now, the scans are run on a weekly basis but we have plans to incorporate a more frequent scanning regiment. 

We already run a custom scanning pipeline and would love to better understand integration paths (API rate limits, auth, audit logs) and whether we can submit our package-lock.json as input to reduce false negatives for UI5/Node/Python stacks.

API findings are returned in the format:

{

  "findings": [{

    "id*": "string",

    "sourceId*": "string",

    "globalAccountId*": "string",

    "subAccountId*": "string",

    "findingId*": "string",

    "description*": "string",

    "recommendation*": "string",

    "cfOrganizationId": "string",

    "cfOrganizationName": "string",

    "appId": "string",

    "appName": "String",

    "lastFound": "Timestamp",

    "firstFound": "Timestamp",

    "assetContext": "string",

    "assetLink": "string",

    "spaceId": "string",

    "spaceName": "string",

    "packageNames": "string[]",

    "activeCves" : "string[]",

    "maxCvss" : "decimal",

    "platform": "string",

    "maxCvssVector": "string",

    "sourceRuleId": "string",

    "priority": "string"

  }]

}

entry.title: 采购含税价税方案进阶-自动带出税率
entry.content:
在这篇博客采购含税价自动计算净价详解中我们着重讨论了在公有云中如何通过增强点实现含税价反算的逻辑细节。为了简化方案，突出重点，原博客里的税率是需要手工输入的。在实际的场景中用户希望税率可以自动带进来，那么在之前增强已经实施的基础上，本篇博客针对这一需求再拓展一些上层配置。

 

更改Z000的类型为D，存储顺序为TTX1

 

  1. MEK1 为Z000维护相应税码，税率也会带出来

 

如果有更细致的需求，比如每一个供应商的税码是不一样的，希望带出的是采购信息记录里维护的税码，采购订单上根据税码带税率。很遗憾采购信息记录里面维护的税率无法带入到定价程序，需要退而求其次的方案，即把存取顺序改成PPR0, 然后去维护一遍所有供应商+物料的税率，可以实现自动过去税率。

 

 

但是相当于对每一个供应商又维护了一遍税的信息记录。工作量较大。这时候可以考虑将供应商按照不同税码分类，借用供应商主数据里的标准字段incoterm来区分不同的税率（前提是某一采购组织下的供应商incoterm没有用到）。 创建自定义的存入顺序ZLQX，维护一张税率和国际贸易术语的条件表。

 

将条件类型Z000的存储顺序换成ZLQX

 

给供应商主数据维护incoterm

 

维护条件表记录

 

测试成功：

 

本文涉及功能基于SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2508版本，后续版本可能会有变化请参考最新信息。如果有帮助到您欢迎点Like，如果有任何问题，关注，点赞，加评论，回复更及时。

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel - New high-volume mode
entry.content:
Since the first release in 2020, SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel has matured to a powerful analytics and planning client embedded in Microsoft Excel.

After adding features like data point commenting, restricted measures or VBA support, we see a lot of customers using the add-in for highly critical business processes such as planning.

However, extracting a high number of cells (>500.000) has led to some challenges. The main challenge is a memory limitation that browsers support for one instance: 4GB. And note: even within Excel desktop, the add-in is running in a browser runtime (i.e., WebView2 or WebKit2). With the given architecture, the add-in could hit this limit easily with about 500.000 to 1.000.000 cells. When this limit was hit, Excel restarts the add-in.

There are scenarios where you need to combine detailed information and the flexibility of Excel calculations. We have been approached by many customers to increase the number of cells that can be displayed in SAC add-in. After a thorough analysis, we chose the way to bypass the SAP Analytics Cloud table (used in the story), which is currently the basis to render the table in Excel. It provides lots of features like number formatting, frontend calculations (insert new rows/columns including formulas), planning and many more. The disadvantage is that this SAC table consumes more memory than necessary for Excel use cases. In the SAC story, this is not so much of a problem as the tables can be read in paging. In Excel, however, the entire table needs to be loaded to support calculations on it.

Our approach is to optimize memory usage by directly reading the pure data information and adding some features on top which were previously offered by SAC table. We decided to have an option to switch from the standard table (using SAC table API) to a memory- and performance-optimized version of it (and back).

In the first version we limited the features for the high-volume mode to the essential ones. For example, planning is not supported – as we assume no planner works on input sheets with millions of cells. Also frontend calculations and comments are not supported in this mode. There are also some limitations that we plan to fix soon such as properties.

In our internal test scenarios we have seen memory consumption reduced – in comparison to the standard mode – by up to factor 10. We could also see performance improvements (end to end) by up to 30% (note that backend and rendering time stay the same, only calculation time is reduced). Of course, for smaller result sets, the difference between the mode is not significant.

In MDS (HANA multi-dimensional services), you will also hit some default values such as the maximum result set size which is set to 1 million cells (result_set_size_max_default). In order to support larger datasets, SAC add-in overrides this value in high-volume mode with the absolute maximum of 10 million cells (result_set_size_max_limit, see SAP note 2770570). The other value for cell size (only needed for internal server calculations) is not changed. As the memory allocation has been optimized, you can also add several tables with altogether more than 10 million cells into the workbook, while for one table the maximum stays with 10 million cells.

In order to activate the high-volume mode, you can use the context menu of the table.

You can switch back and forth between the modes. The default for new tables is the standard mode. You can use the pause/refresh feature for adding a new table and switch them to high-volume mode before the table is rendered.

When comparing performance, you can use the profiling information that you can activate in the workbook preferences.

This generates an additional sheet that provides information how much time is spent in different layers and how much memory is used.

entry.title: Re: Generic IDoc Outbound flow in Cloud Integration Pipeline
entry.content:
Hello @iignatius,

If you want to consume an event from SAP Event Mesh in an SAP Cloud Integration iFlow (rather than delivering the event directly to the receiver) you can use the Pipeline Framework.

How to implement depends on the event type:

  • Notification events: If you need data enrichment (for example, lookups or formatting), use Step 03 (Inbound Conversion) to enrich the payload and then Step 07.
  • Data events: If you must transform the message or deliver it via a protocol that Event Mesh does not support, use only a scenario‑specific Step 07 (Outbound) to perform the transformation and handle protocol-specific delivery to the target receiver.

Key difference versus IDocs:

  • With IDocs, you configure the BD64 distribution model in the sender backend for each receiver.
  • With events, you publish once (“fire and forget”) to Event Mesh, which routes to all subscribed receivers - no per-receiver communication IDoc is needed in the backend.
  • If a receiver cannot consume events directly from Event Mesh, you can place Cloud Integration in between and leverage the Pipeline Framework for enrichment, transformation, and delivery.

Hope this clarifies the approach.

entry.title: Re: 📢 Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
Why restrict the choice to 2 options only?

Typically, SAP follows a generic, flexible approach, i.e. a generic, parameterized default solution, which could be overruled or adapted by customers.

I'd suggest to introduce a Fiori app to cover simple cases plus a BAdI to cover specific requirements, so that a customer could implement its needs. This BAdI could receive the following input parameters as context:

  • System/Runtime type
  • Software Component
  • ABAP Language Version
  • Object Type
  • Package
  • etc.

The result could be either a naming proposal or simply a boolean value (naming convention matched: yes/no)

For me, a Naming Convention looks like a "Business Rule for Developers" - so perhaps a corresponding framework could be used in the implementation? 

Please apply the Naming Convention to all (new) generators, e.g. for Business Configuration. Ideally the new solution offers a "Test" and "Consistency Check" feature.

entry.title: Signavio Process Insights and Process Intelligence - an unexpected journey
entry.content:
2025 is on the last mile and I'm about to finalize my work for SAP Signavio Process Analysis and Mining (PA&M). Looking back to when I started it feels like thinking about "the good old times" and "an unexpected journey", although it's only 2.5 years ago. Since then we almost tripled the number of customers and for 3 years in a row we were leaders in Gartner's Magic Quadrant. 
Did I expect that? For sure not, but in hindsight I can share my learning and my personal cook book for enterprise software development success.

When I joined Signavio Process Insights (internally known as PINS) as Chief Product Owner in August 2023 (NOW release 2505 & THEN release 2310), we were a small but mighty team of about 50 people. With just over ~330 customers, and a rather longish time frame until customers started actively using their tenants. Our growth ambition was sky-high, but the team was ready to reach for the stars. At the same time, Process Intelligence (internally known as PINT) had a similar number of customers. Our biggest challenge was changing the perception that both products were just the result of the clash between Signavio acquisition and SAP's own developed BTP solution and either the one or the other will be discontinued.

Fast forward to today: We can proudly look back on an incredible joint growth story for both solutions with tripled number of customers and we will see the solutions growing closer and closer together with every release. A very bright example of this is Plug and Gain with which we built the bridge to connect both solutions under the hood and the first step to a joint PA&M solution. And even more: I'm very proud that we are on our way for the general availability of the recently announced PA&M unification, which is the long awaited first step for the new Signavio suite user experience. 

Here is my personal cook book for software engineering success at SAP:

  1. 2309 The "old" Start Page: Start simple with high value use cases and free usage (the Discovery Edition) and then...
  2. 2311 Fiori Horizon user experience: ...make user experience consistent, by leveraging SAP Fiori as the standard for all solutions...
  3. 2402 Internationalization: ...scale globally by adding 7 new languages,...
  4. 2405 Transformation Manager: ...show progress in a 360 degree transformation initiative view in the Signavio suite ...
  5. 2407 Attribute-based authorization: ...scale for large enterprises by introducing access control on organizational level,...
  6. 2408 Plug&Gain as PINS Service and PINT Connector: ...deep integration out-of-the-box,...
  7. 2411 Personal Dashboards as start page: ...bring hidden gems to the front door, by allowing users to build dashboards for their interest topics...
  8. 2505 Improvement Opportunity Dashboards: ...explain deep insights for everybody, and retain Gartner MQ leadership in 2025... 
  9. 2509 Semantic Search (Beta): ...provide the contextual foundation for AI-Agents..

     

Here you can learn more about Process Analysis and Mining:

  1. See SAP Signavio Process Insights, Process Intelligence and Plug & Gain in action
  2. Your first steps to get started with SAP Signavio Process Insights
  3. Who do I need to involve and which challenges do I want to solve?
  4. How to start your analysis?
  5. “Cash is King” - but how to become royal? - SAP Community
  6. Why are there two business process analysis soluti... - SAP Community
  7. Plug & Gain:
    • Plug & Gain Video Series and Plug & Gain OpenSAP
    • How to use the Plug & Gain Connector
    • Optimize financial closing process with Plug & Gain
  1. SAP Analytics Cloud Content for Process Insights
  2. SAP Learning:
    SAP Signavio Process Analysis
    SAP Signavio Process Management & Design
    SAP Signavio Solution Configuration
  3. Partner Edge (Login required): Webinar Series for Process Insights

entry.title: Inbound Process - Oriented storage control (POSC) Deconsolidation process
entry.content:
1. Configuration

1.1 Define work center

SPRO –> IMG—> SCM Extended warehouse management –> Extended warehouse management –> Master Data –> Define work center.

 Figure 1

 

1.2 Define Process-Oriented Storage process control (POSC)

SPRO –> IMG—> SCM Extended warehouse management –> Extended warehouse management –> Cross-process settings –> Warehouse Task –> Define Process-Oriented Storage process control.

  Figure 2

3 SAP standard external steps IB01, IB02, IB03 are assigned to 3 internal process steps(UNLO,SPR,PUT)

 Figure 3

To the Warehouse assign the external process steps, source storage type and destination storage type, also destination bins.

 Figure 4

 

1.3 Check the Warehouse process type 3065 , 3060 and 1011

SPRO –> IMG—> SCM Extended warehouse management –> Extended warehouse management –> Cross-process settings –> Warehouse Task –> Define Warehouse process type.

 Figure 5

The WPT 3065 will determine the source storage type and bin as shown above.

 Figure 6

 

1.4 Determine Warehouse process type

SPRO –> IMG—> SCM Extended warehouse management –> Extended warehouse management –> Cross-process settings –> Warehouse Task –> Determine Warehouse process type.

 

 Figure 7

Process type determination indicator for WPT 1011 is IB that is assigned to Warehouse.

 

Process Steps

1.Create Material Master

Create materials by selecting required views.

In /n/scwm/MAT1, Maintain process type determine indicator(WPT indicator) as IB for both materials and 

Putaway control indicator 0020 for 1st product and 0021 for 2nd product as shown in figure below.

 

 Figure 8

 

2.Create purchase order

Create a purchase order in ERP system (T code ME21N), verify the vendor, plant and storage location for the entered products. The confirmation key for the PO line item should allow the creation of inbound deliveries.

 

3.Create an Inbound delivery

Create an inbound delivery in ERP system (T code VL31N),in the delivery detail screen, enter the delivery quantity.in the packing screen, pack the product into HU, since HU is a requirement for both POSC & LOSC. Once the required data is entered save the data in the inbound delivery, this will create an inbound delivery in the ERP system and will be transferred to EWM system for further processing.

 Figure 9

 

5.Maintain Inbound delivery

Maintain Inbound delivery in EWM system using T code /N/SCWM/PRDI, paste the inbound delivery created in the ERP system and execute it, do unloading and goods receipt as shown in figure 10.

 Figure 10

 

Display the Inbound delivery in the warehouse monitor (T code /N/SCWM/MON), Here 3 warehouse tasks will be created

 Figure 11

  • Warehouse task  is created in background for the step IB01 and the second step is in open status , for moving the Source HU from the source storage type 9010 to destination storage type 8010. Since Warehouse task is open based on the settings made in WPT 3060

  • Other task is created and closed, It is for moving the HU from S.type9030 to S.type 9010, it is automatically closed based on settings made in the WPT 3065.Before deconsolidation we need to confirm the warehouse task

6. Deconsolidation using T code /N/SCWM/DCONS

do the deconsolidation at 8010(work center DEKO) by breaking HU and repacking with different HU and move those to destination storage types 0020 and 0021.

Pass the HU number and then execute

 Figure 12

Before unpack we need to create the packaging material.

Enter packaging material: PALLET and execute.

 Figure 13

Now go to deconsolidation tab and enter the source HU number as shown below and click on warehouse tasks and select the task, destination HU will be automatically taken and click on execute

 Figure 14

Select the  HU and complete the deconsolidation process as shown below and repeat the same for other HU also. 

 Figure 15

Now both the tasks are open status as shown below, select line and confirm the task in background

 Figure 16

 

7. Stock check in the monitor  (T code/N/SCWM/MON)

finally in the monitor check the stock and bin, both the HU'S will be placed in the respective storage type and bin as per the POSC configuration made, as shown in figure 17.

 Figure 17

 

Conclusion:

From the above steps, one can understand how to configure Inbound Process-Oriented Storage control (POSC) In Deconsolidation process, by following the above steps one can have a clear idea on how to use POSC concept In Deconsolidation process and can implement the same depends on the  business requirement.

 

References:

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blogs-by-members/layout-oriented-storage-contro...

www.ewmguru.com

www.sap-press.com

 

Pre requisite: Should have Basic knowledge of SAP Extended Warehouse Management.

 

Please like, share and comment for any queries through add comment button which is displayed at bottom of the blog-post.

For any queries, please post your question by using the following link

https://community.sap.com/t5/c-khhcw49343/SAP+Extended+Warehouse+Management/pd-p/0120061532080000070...

Hope this blog-post will be help full

 

Thank you

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud + Sales Performance Management: Drive Sales with Clarity and Confidence
entry.content:
Imagine this: Your sales team is motivated, aligned, and focused. Quotas are clear. Incentives are fair. Performance insights are at your fingertips. That’s not a dream, it’s what happens when SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Sales Performance Management (SPM) work together.

The Challenge

Sales leaders often struggle with fragmented tools, unclear incentive plans, and limited visibility. Sellers waste time chasing numbers instead of customers. Managers lack real-time insights to coach effectively. Operations teams fight complexity instead of driving efficiency.

The Solution

SAP Sales Cloud and SAP SPM combine to deliver a single, intelligent solution. Together, they:

  • Unify insights: Compensation plans, quotas, and performance data in one place.
  • Motivate sellers: Transparent incentives and accurate earnings calculations.
  • Empower managers: Real-time dashboards for coaching and pipeline decisions.
  • Streamline operations: Automated workflows and reduced administrative overhead.

With advanced analytics and AI-driven recommendations, you can predict outcomes, adjust plans, and keep your team focused on what matters—selling.

The Outcome

When SPM is embedded into SAP Sales Cloud, productivity soars. Sellers trust the process. Managers lead with confidence. Operations run smoothly. The entire organization becomes informed, motivated, and rewarded for success.

Want to go deeper?

Explore our SAP Customer Experience Value Map and unlock guided learning, best practices, and expert support:

  • Sales Cloud Value Map – Version 1
  • Sales Cloud Value Map – Version 2

And if you’re ready to master incentive management, check out the Sales Performance Management TKB 

 

About the author: 

Edmar Rodríguez is a Topic Expert for SAP Enterprise Support value maps, specializing in SAP Customer Experience. With 12 years of experience at SAP and a background spanning roles in various customer support positions, Edmar is passionate about helping customers succeed through SAP Enterprise Support offerings.

entry.title: MRP MD01N: Inconsistent Component PR Creation and Stock Consideration Behavior with/without Subcon.
entry.content:
Dear team,

 

Issue Summary:
When executing MRP Live (MD01N), the system shows inconsistent behavior for component purchase requisition (PR) creation and stock consideration depending on whether Subcontracting MRP Area configuration is active.

 

Prerequisite Configuration Setup:

  • MRP Area type (MDLV-BERTY) = 02 – Storage Location is configured.

 

Prerequisite Master Data Setup:

  • Component material Issuing Storage Location (STPO-LGORT) is maintained in the Bill of Materials (BOM).
  • Corresponding Storage Location type MRP Area is assigned in the component material master MRP1 view (MDMA)

 

Requirements summary:

Requirement#

Description

1

Component PR to be created at BU level MRP Area - When the component material Issuing storage location (STPO-LGORT) is set in the Bill of Materials (BOM), the component purchase requisition (PR) should be created at the BU level MRP area of Component material Issuing storage location (STPO-LGORT).

2

Component Stock of BU level MRP Area should be considered - When the component material Issuing storage location (STPO-LGORT) is set in the Bill of Materials (BOM), the component stock of storage location of respective BU level MRP area should be considered, and system should not consider neighbor BU level MRP area stock.

3

Component Stock at subcon Vendor Location should be considered during planning run – Unnecessary PR should not be created if sufficient component stock is available at Subcon Vendor location

 

 

Observed Behavior:

Scenario

Req#1 – PR created in Storage loc. MRP area

Req#2 – Stock from Storage loc. MRP area considered

Req#3 – Stock from Subcon vendor location considered

Without Subcontracting MRP Area configuration

Yes

Yes

No

With Subcontracting MRP Area configuration

No

No

Yes

 

Expected Behavior:
The MD01N should:

  • Create PRs in the storage location type MRP area of issuing storage location (STPO-LGORT)
  • Consider stock from the same MRP area.
  • Consider stock from the subcontracting vendor location.

Scenario

Req#1

Req#2

Req#3

With or without Subcon MRP Area configuration

Yes

Yes

Yes

 

Preference:

  1. Preferred Option: Meet all three requirements without activating subcontracting MRP area configuration.
  2. Alternative Option: Meet all three requirements with subcontracting MRP area configuration active.

 

Business Impact:

  • Unnecessary PRs are generated even though there is enough stock in subcontracting vendor’s storage location.
  • Available component stock at the vendor location, Storage location level MRP area is not effectively utilized.
  • leads to excess procurement, higher inventory, and inaccurate MRP planning results.

 

Questions to SCN.

  • Is there any SAP standard configuration or master data setting available to meet all three requirements simultaneously?
  • Could you please confirm whether there is any SAP Note available to achieve this behavior?

 

Thanks & Regards,

Manoahr

entry.title: Re: Mass Download Line Items in General Ledger
entry.content:
This is the current limitation in Excel spreadsheets from Microsoft. This is the workaround:

In the APP: Display Line Items in General Ledger filter for posting date as "Last quarter" and click go. Then export the data to Excel. If the same error still does come up then reduce it to one month. If this is still too large then reduce it to 2 weeks. KBA 3639629 - In Display Line Items in General Ledger app, large amounts of data can’t be exported at one time

entry.title: SAP to Collaborate with AWS to bring the SAP BTP ABAP Environment to Arm-Based AWS Graviton
entry.content:
Authors: Steven Jones (AWS), Sonja Liénard (SAP)

The key to SAP’s innovation and adoption success has always been its openness, supporting diverse hardware platforms, networks, and technology ecosystems, while offering flexible deployment options for customers operating in mixed and heterogeneous environments. This principle extends to the ABAP Platform and especially the BTP ABAP Environment, which powers next-generation ABAP Cloud applications and extensions. Beyond this openness, SAP is leveraging innovative technologies like AWS's ARM-based Graviton processors. Today, we are excited to announce the evolution of that partnership:

SAP and AWS will collaborate to bring the SAP BTP ABAP environment to Arm-based AWS Graviton processors.

 

A Longstanding History of Co-Innovation in the Cloud

Since 2008, SAP partnered with AWS to help customers leverage cloud innovations. In 2023, we announced that SAP HANA Cloud runs on AWS Graviton, a custom-built chip by AWS that delivers price, performance, and energy efficiency benefits for cloud workloads. By initially migrating SAP HANA Cloud to AWS Graviton3-based Amazon EC2 instances, SAP has seen up to 30% better compute performance for analytical workloads and lowered its compute carbon footprint by an estimated 45%. Building on these experiences, SAP and AWS have been continuously innovating to further improve the performance of SAP HANA Cloud.

Driving Flexibility and Performance

SAP BTP ABAP environment is the platform as a service offering for ABAP developers. It’s a cloud-optimized ABAP platform based on SAP HANA Cloud that serves as a development and runtime environment for cloud applications.

Initial tests have shown positive results for ABAP on AWS Graviton architectures, demonstrating strong performance and efficiency gains. With the extensive breadth of Amazon EC2 instance families available on Arm, SAP will be able to select the right instance type and size optimized for ABAP workloads and leverage this diverse portfolio for maximum instance flexibility for our customers.

Why Arm and AWS Graviton?

With AWS Graviton3-based instances, SAP experienced up to 35% price-performance improvement for analytics workloads, and a reduction of the compute carbon footprint of SAP HANA Cloud workloads. With AWS Graviton4-based instances, we’ve seen an up to 25% additional performance improvement for analytical and up to 40% additional improvement for transactional workloads compared to AWS Graviton3-based instances.

Now, with the next AWS Graviton5-based Amazon EC2 M9g instances, we’ve observed a 35-60% increase in the performance of our OLTP queries on SAP HANA Cloud in a single generation. Based on the performance improvements demonstrated in SAP HANA Cloud with AWS Graviton processors, SAP is confident the SAP BTP ABAP environment will also leverage AWS Graviton technology to deliver similar benefits.

A Strategic Partnership for Sustainability

This new collaboration continues our shared commitment to sustainability. SAP is a signatory of Amazon’s Climate Pledge and has accelerated its own sustainability commitment to 2030. Our journey with AWS Graviton aligns perfectly with those goals, and we are eager to see what additional improvements in energy efficiency we can realize together in the future.

What’s Next?

Porting the SAP BTP ABAP environment to AWS Graviton involves adapting its cloud-native architecture, including containerized services and runtime components, to Arm. SAP and AWS teams will continue developing, testing, and working on performance optimization pipelines to ensure a seamless experience for customers.

We look forward to sharing more updates on this project and the value it brings in terms of performance, reliability, and sustainability. Stay tuned as we continue this journey together.

entry.title: Re: Adding Country/Region after Deploy in CBC System
entry.content:
Hi!

In SAP Central Business Configuration, adding a Country/Region to the Scope is a supported Self-Service activity, meaning it can be performed directly by the user.

To proceed with the Country/Region addition, the Workspace must be in the “Scope and Organizational Structure” phase. If the Workspace is currently in the “Product-Specific Configuration” phase (after deploying the Workspace), the Define Scope app must be Reopened before continuing to the Country/Region addition.

For the detailed steps on how to perform the Country/Region addition, please refer to the following KBA: 3438273 - How to Add a Country/Region in SAP Central Business Configuration Workspace - SAP for Me

Additional information can be found in:

  • Country/Region-Specific Scoping and Configuration | SAP Help Portal
  • Changes via Edit | SAP Help Portal

Best Regards,

entry.title: Re: unable to find license catogary for purchase requestion
entry.content:
Hi,

Please refer to the KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/0003631390

  • The app My Purchase Requisitions- New can be used. This new self-service procurement app serves to offer the employees or casual users a consolidated one-stop solution that provides a quick, intuitive, and efficient shopping experience.
  • This app is available using the business role SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE_PROCUREMENT and business catalog SAP_MM_BC_SSPPR_MANAGE_PC. 

Also as per KBA  3631973 - The app 'Display Purchase Requisitions' is Advanced priced category instead of Self Servi… 

Certain apps such as Display Purchase Requisitions require an "Advanced" license due to the complexity and breadth of functionality they offer. These apps enable users to perform advanced tasks and often include features beyond basic transaction processing. This contrasts with "Core" or "Self-Service" apps, which focus on standard business processes or user-specific tasks.

In this scenario, the Self-Service procurement app 'My Purchase Requisitions- New' can be used. With this app, as an employee or casual user can do the following:

  • Create, view, edit, copy, and delete self-service purchase requisitions.
  • Track the status and process flow of your purchase requisitions.
  • Confirm the receipt of goods.
  • Return the received goods in case of any issues or defects.

Thank you,

SAP Support

entry.title: How to remove order reasons

Is it possible to remove order reasons on the configuration activity ? I have some unwanted order reasons (with empty description) and I'd like to delete them.

Best regards.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to remove order reasons
entry.content:
Hello,

The order reasons can be deleted when they're not being referenced by any document.

You can check how many orders reference an order reason by going to the 'Manage Sales Orders' and filtering by the concerned order reason. If there's no sales order for the order reason, then it can be deleted.

Kind regards.

  • User Z: can only load USA & Canada only related legal entities

Thank you a lot,
Déborah A.

entry.title: Re: Confirmation of combined Orders in Mill_OC
entry.content:
Hi BHBCK - When you combined your orders using MILL_OC I assume that after combining the orders you also combined your first 10 operations only. You did not combine the subsequent operations.  After you use COHV to mass release all of the orders in the combination (the 1 lead/header order and all of the children orders) you will confirm your header order first to confirm your common operations. Then each child order "goes its own way" and you confirm them separately. The final operation of your child orders will have the goods receipts for each product you are making.  The header order likely has the 261 movement of the raw material.  

I am also new to MILL Products but the steps I described above work for us.

What is a big pain/surprise is that we cannot use CO19 Time Event confirmations; we must use CO11N Time Ticket confirmations.  The SAP Help does not say this.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere & Google BigQuery: 3 Integration Strategies Before Zero Copy via BDC Connect Arrives
entry.content:
Hello guys, how are you?

SAP and Google announced at the last SAP Connect that in H1-2026 we will have Zero Copy using BDC connect between SAP Business Data Cloud and Google BigQuery.

 

Today, our Databricks zero-copy strategy is powered by Delta Sharing. This technology, created by Databricks, enables the secure and rapid sharing of data stored in Delta Lake without the need for file replication.

What is Delta Share / Zero Copy ?

Imagine you have a Data Lake (full of Parquet, CSV, JSON files, etc.).

Then someone comes along and says

"Hey, I need access to this data!"

Normally, you would have to:

  • send the files (copies),
  • or grant access to the storage,
  • or create an API.

Delta Share / Zero Copy simplifies this:

It allows you to share data directly from Delta Lake, in Delta Table format, without moving the files. The recipient of access can read the data live, as if it were a local table — and with:

  • security (permission control),
  • consistency (no one gets corrupted or incomplete data),
  • and automatic updates (if the data changes, the consumer sees the updated version).

We can find more information about Zero Copy with Google BigQuery at this link : https://news.sap.com/2025/10/sap-google-cloud-redefine-enterprise-ai-zero-copy-data-google-bigquery/

However, until this connector is available, we can currently use three methods to integrate SAP Datasphere and Google Big Query, which are:

  • Data Federation: Google BigQuery -> SAP Datasphere
  • Data Federation: SAP Datasphere -> Google BigQuery
  • SAP HANA ML or FED ML in Jupyter Notebooks embedded in Google BigQuery

First, what is data federation?

Data federation is an approach that allows access to and querying of information stored in different sources without needing to move or duplicate that data to a single repository. Instead of making copies, federation creates a virtual layer that connects systems and allows data to be consumed in real time, directly from its origins. In the context of SAP Datasphere, data federation allows the integration of external platforms—such as Google BigQuery, AWS Athena, or Azure Synapse—keeping the data where it is, but with the ability to combine and analyze it along with information from the SAP ecosystem. This approach reduces redundancies, improves governance, and ensures always up-to-date access to information, without sacrificing performance and security.

1. Data Federation : Google Big Query ->  SAP Datasphere

The federation between SAP Datasphere and Google BigQuery allows you to access BigQuery data directly in SAP Datasphere without replicating the data, creating virtual tables that aggregate data from different sources without duplicating them. (link : https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/data-federation-in-datasphere/ba-p/13750166 )

Example : 

A common scenario would be a company that has transactional data in SAP S/4HANA and market analysis data in Google BigQuery. Through federation, you can create views that combine sales data from SAP with market trend data from BigQuery, enabling integrated analysis without moving the data from their original locations. The result is a unified view of the data that can be consumed by SAP Analytics Cloud for visualizations and reporting.

 

Below are some steps to use this architecture:

1 - Configure Google BigQuery in SAP Datasphere.

2 - Select the table from SAP BigQuery and import its metadata into SAP Datasphere.

3 - Creating a model by combining data from SAP Datasphere and Google BigQuery.

 

Here at the Discovery Center, you have a step-by-step guide on how to configure and access Google BigQuery data federation in SAP Datasphere. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/3409/?tab=projectboard

Advantages of this approach

  1. Unified analytics - You combine BigQuery data with SAP information (ERP, BW, HANA, etc.) in a single analytical environment.
  1. No data movement - SAP Datasphere accesses data directly from BigQuery—no copies, ETL, or extra storage costs.
  1. Real-time access - Queries reflect the most recent BigQuery data, always up-to-date.
  1. Preserved governance and security - Google Cloud access and control rules remain in effect, ensuring end-to-end security.
  1. Use of the SAP ecosystem - Allows you to use SAP Datasphere resources (modeling, Data Marketplace, SAP semantics) with BigQuery data.
  2. Scalability and performance - SAP Datasphere leverages BigQuery performance for federated queries on large volumes of data.
  3. Simpler and more flexible architecture - Fewer integrations and pipelines—you choose when to federate or, if you prefer, materialize the data in SAP.

2.  Data Federation :  SAP Datasphere -> Google Big Query

This approach to data federation between SAP Datasphere and Google BigQuery allows you to access data from SAP Datasphere directly in Google BigQuery without replicating the data, or, if you prefer, materializing the data in SAP.

For this approach, we configured a federated SAP HANA connection in Google BigQuery with these steps:

Step 1 - Create a user database in an SAP Datasphere space

Step 2 - Enable the "Expose for consumption" toggle in the SAP Datasphere view

Step 3 - Create the federated connection within Google BigQuery

Step 4 - Create a federated query in Google BigQuery

 

Step 1 - Create a user database in an SAP Datasphere space

In this step, we will create a database user in SAP Datasphere.

To do this, click on SPACE Management and then on the space where you are creating your objects, clicking on EDIT.

 

Click on the Database Access section.

In Database user, click CREATE.

Enter the username and check the ENABLE READ SQL box as shown in the image below, then click create.

Save and then deploy it.

After deployment is complete, the user will be ready to use the system. Click the "I" icon to retrieve the user's credentials.

Click on Request new password to obtain the password generated by Datasphere:

Save the information for later use.

 

Step 2 - Enable the "Expose for consumption" toggle in the SAP Datasphere view

Open the view you want to access in Google BigQuery and enable the "expose for consumption" toggle, as shown in the image below.

 

Step 3 - Create the federated connection within Google BigQuery

In Google Big Query, click on connection

 

Click on Create Connection

Select SAP HANA and configure the endpoint with the user database created in the first step;

 

Step 4 - Create a federated query in Google BigQuery

With this configuration, we can access the SAP Datasphere views that have the "expose for consumption" toggle enabled directly in Google BigQuery, as shown in the query below:

 

SELECT * FROM EXTERNAL_QUERY("XXX.us.DATASPHERE", "SELECT * FROM FINANCIAL_USER.V_FIXED_ASSET");

 

Advantages of this approach

  1. Centralized analytics - You query SAP data directly in BigQuery, along with other sources (Google Ads, CRM, etc.), all in one place.
  1. No data duplication - Data remains in SAP, avoiding copies, storage costs, and ETL pipelines.
  1. Real-time access - Queries read data directly from the source—always up-to-date, without waiting for nightly loads.
  1. Maintained governance - SAP security and access rules are respected; BigQuery only reads what is permitted.
  1. Use of Google tools - Allows you to use the Google ecosystem (Looker, Vertex AI, Dataform, etc.) with SAP data, without moving anything. 
  1. Scalability and performance - BigQuery processes heavy queries quickly, even with large volumes of federated data.
  2. Simpler and more flexible architecture - Fewer integrations, less maintenance, and freedom to decide what to federate or materialize.

 

3.  SAP HANA ML or FED ML in Jupyter Notebooks embedded in Google Big Query

In this approach, we can transform a table or query from SAP Datasphere into a dataframe directly in Google BigQuery.

What are these libraries?

Firstly, hana-ml library is a Python client library that allows data scientists to access SAP HANA data and build machine learning models using the data directly in SAP HANA, without needing to move data between the server and the client. The library provides a Python interface to SAP HANA's machine learning capabilities, including access to the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) and Automated Predictive Library (APL) algorithms. (https://pypi.org/project/hana-ml/)

FED ML, or Federated Machine Learning, is a Python library developed to solve a specific problem: connecting SAP business data to external Artificial Intelligence environments (Hyperscalers) efficiently and without excessive duplication. This library allows Data Scientists to work on platforms like AWS SageMaker, Azure ML, or Google Vertex AI, using open-source libraries (such as TensorFlow, PyTorch, or Scikit-learn), consuming data directly from SAP Datasphere without the need to create complex ETL (Extraction, Transformation, and Loading) pipelines. (https://github.com/SAP-samples/datasphere-fedml ).

Below is an example using the Jupyter notebook from Google Big Query consuming an object from SAP Datasphere with the hana-ml library.

To Create a Jupyter Notebook in Bigquery, click on Notebook

And then New Notebook

First, let's install the hana-ml library.

 

pip install hana-ml

Import HANA ML library 

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import hana_ml.dataframe as dataframe

Establish a connection to SAP Datasphere with the credential created in the step above:

 

import hana_ml.dataframe as dataframe

conn = dataframe.ConnectionContext(address='xxxxxxxxx.hana.prod-xx.hanacloud.ondemand.com', port=443,user='FINANCIAL_USER#DEMOBQ')
                                 
conn.connection.isconnected()

 

Add the table to a DataFrame.

df_sales_document_ml = conn.table("V_SALESDOCUMENT_ML_SHARED", schema="FINANCIAL_USER")

Result :

Now, you can use this object within the Jupyter notebook embedded in Google BigQuery and combine this data with data from Google BigQuery.

 

Advantages of this approach

 

  1. Unified View (360º) - You cross-reference financial and inventory data from SAP with behavioral and marketing data from Google (Analytics, Ads) in the same notebook, creating much richer predictive models.
  1. Elastic Infrastructure - You train heavyweight models using the  Google cloud (including GPUs), without crashing your local computer or depending on its limited memory.
  2. Accelerated AI Cycle - The developed model can quickly become a service (API), as the development environment is already integrated with the production and governance tools of Google Vertex AI.

 

Conclusion

In this blog, we explore 3 ways to integrate SAP Datasphere with Google BigQuery, serving as robust alternatives until the arrival of 'Zero Copy' functionality via BDC Connect, scheduled for the first half of 2026.

entry.title: Re: Implications of Functional User license for Contingent workers when using onboarding
entry.content: From my understanding if the contingent worker originates in SAP FieldGlass, since you are paying a licensing fee  for FG then you shouldn’t pay an EC, functional or not. At least I hope as we are exploring this path
